title: 109_hr3729
content: The Act titled "Federal Judiciary Emergency Tolling Act of 2006" allows for the emergency authority to delay or toll judicial proceedings. The "Federal Judiciary Emergency Tolling Act of 2006" grants emergency authority to district court chief judges to delay or toll judicial deadlines in the event of natural disasters or emergencies affecting court operations. The "Federal Judiciary Emergency Tolling Act of 2006" grants district court chief judges the authority to extend time deadlines for various legal proceedings, excluding limitations for criminal and civil actions. The "Federal Judiciary Emergency Tolling Act of 2006" allows district court chief judges to extend time deadlines for legal proceedings, excluding limitations for criminal and civil actions. If the chief judge is unavailable, the authority can be exercised by the senior district judge or the chief judge of the circuit. This section does not authorize the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus. The "Federal Judiciary Emergency Tolling Act of 2006" allows district court chief judges to extend time deadlines for legal proceedings in criminal cases during emergency situations. The chief judge of a court of appeals can also exercise emergency authority to toll deadlines in the event of a natural disaster or other emergency affecting the courts. The chief judge of a court of appeals can exercise emergency authority to delay, toll, or grant relief from time deadlines for cases pending in the court. If the chief judge is unavailable, the authority can be exercised by the senior circuit judge. The Attorney General or their designee can request an order under this section. The General's designee or the chief judge of a district or circuit can request or act on an order under this section. The duration of orders issued under this section cannot extend deadlines for more than 14 days, unless additional extensions are approved by the chief judge with consent from the judicial council. Courts issuing orders under this section must make efforts to publicize the order on relevant websites. Courts issuing orders under this section must notify the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate and the House of Representatives. They are also required to submit a report to the Committees and the Judicial Conference of the United States within 180 days after the orders end, detailing the reasons for issuing the orders and their duration. Courts issuing orders under this section must notify the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate and the House of Representatives. They are also required to submit a report to the Committees and the Judicial Conference of the United States within 180 days after the orders end, detailing the reasons for issuing the orders, their duration, effects on litigants, and costs to the judiciary. Exceptions apply for orders that toll or extend deadlines for less than 14 days. Emergency authority to delay or toll judicial deadlines was passed by the House of Representatives on July 17, 2006. Karen L. Haas attested to this.
